Assets.Functionality: Qualifies peripheral bus access and gates register read/write within the GPIO address space.
Assets.Justification: If an attacker can assert/deassert the enable at the wrong time, writes could be dropped or unintended registers accessed. Preserving the correctness of bus qualification is essential to keep GPIO configuration state from being corrupted.

Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1262: Improper access control for the peripheral enable signal could allow unauthorized manipulation of GPIO register access, compromising integrity.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1280: If access control checks for the peripheral enable are delayed, unauthorized access to GPIO registers could occur before validation, risking integrity.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1220: Insufficient granularity in access control for the peripheral enable could allow unauthorized agents to access or modify GPIO registers, violating integrity.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-680: CAPEC-680 can exploit CWE-1262 by manipulating the 'per_en' signal timing to cause incorrect peripheral bus access, compromising the integrity of the GPIO configuration state by allowing unintended register writes or reads.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: CAPEC-74 can exploit CWE-1262 by inducing a race condition on the 'per_en' signal, leading to unauthorized access or modification of GPIO registers, thereby violating the integrity of the peripheral bus qualification process.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: CAPEC-180 exploits CWE-1280 by manipulating the 'per_en' signal to improperly qualify peripheral bus access, potentially leading to unauthorized register writes and compromising the integrity of the GPIO configuration state.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: CAPEC-74 targets CWE-1280 by intercepting and altering the 'per_en' signal timing, causing unintended register access and undermining the integrity of the GPIO module's configuration.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: By exploiting CWE-1220, an attacker using CAPEC-180 could manipulate the 'per_en' signal timing to cause unauthorized register access, compromising the integrity of the GPIO configuration state.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: Through CWE-1220, CAPEC-74 enables an attacker to disrupt the 'per_en' signal, leading to incorrect bus qualification and potential corruption of the GPIO configuration state, thus violating its integrity.

Assets.Functionality: Selects which byte(s) of the targeted register are written (high/low) during a bus transaction.
Assets.Justification: Manipulating write strobes can partially overwrite control registers, leading to inconsistent configuration. Correct write granularity is required to preserve register integrity.

Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1262: Improper access control for register interfaces can allow unauthorized manipulation of the peripheral write enable byte strobes, leading to partial overwrites and inconsistent configuration.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1220: Insufficient granularity of access control could allow unauthorized agents to manipulate the peripheral write enable byte strobes, compromising the integrity of register writes.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1224: Improper restriction of write-once bit fields could allow repeated manipulation of the peripheral write enable byte strobes, leading to unauthorized reconfiguration of control registers.
